The Employment Appeal Tribunal (EAT) has upheld a decision that calling someone bald amounted to sex-related harassment ğŸ’¡ The EAT heard an appeal from British Bung Company, a manufacturer of wooden cask closures for the brewing industry, which argued that the original employment tribunal decision in 2022 had interpreted discrimination law too broadly ğŸ¤” The original tribunal ruled that electrician Tony Finn had been subjected to sex-related harassment by his factory supervisor, Jamie King, who had twice referred to him as a "bald ****" ğŸ˜© The EAT judge said that the original tribunal was right to find that there was a connection between the word "bald" and the protected characteristic of sex ğŸ‘¨ The EAT judge also said that the original tribunal was right to find that the comments made by King were personally offensive to Finn and that they created an intimidating environment for him ğŸ˜Ÿ The EAT upheld the original tribunal's decision, ruling that insulting a man for being bald does count as sex-related harassment âš–ï¸ Supportis are experts in #HumanResources, #EmploymentLawUK and #HealthAndSafety for #UKBusiness like yours, posting #HRNews for employers every weekday âœ”ï¸ Book a fast, free, no-obligation chat with our friendly team today ğŸ™‹â™€ï¸ ğŸ“± 0161 603 2156 ğŸ’» supportis.com ğŸ’Œ hello@supportis.com ğŸ’¬ DM us #LondonBusiness #BirminghamBusiness #ManchesterBusiness #LeedsBusiness #GlasgowBusiness #LiverpoolBusiness #SheffieldBusiness #EdinburghBusiness #BristolBusiness #NottinghamBusiness #CoventryBusiness #LeicesterBusiness #ReadingBusiness #SouthamptonBusiness #NewcastleBusiness #MiltonKeynesBusiness #WarringtonBusiness #BrightonBusiness #CardiffBusiness #NorthWestBusiness #BasildonBusiness #ChesterBusiness #stockportbusiness

DAY 3 OF THE SPD LEADERSHIP SERIES Deputy Chief Rusty M., of the COFCDPS, began the day by discussing servant leadership. Throughout each day of this series, I have been drawing stars next to statements made that I felt drawn to. This portion regarding servant leadership made me really master how to draw a star because I drew so many during it. With that being said, it made it extremely difficult to cram everything into one post. Deputy Chief Rusty M., introduced this leadership style by stating the following, â€œIt is not about telling your people what to do, itâ€™s about taking care of your people.â€ This really connected with me because of how overwhelming important my family is to me. When I say family, it does not only include those who I am blood related to. For me, family extends past that and extends to my police â€œbrothers and sistersâ€. That was why my departure from the Culpeper Police Department was so hard on me. I developed a bond with my brothers and sisters at that department that made each one of them feel like a part of my family. I have been extremely lucky to be accepted with open arms to the family at the College of Charleston Department of Public Safety. It is very evident that my command staff believe in this leadership style. As I grow in my career in policing, I plan to form my leadership style around this idea. This style can be easily accomplished my making sure you do one simple task. That task is LISTENING. Deputy Chief Rusty M. stated the following, â€œYou were given two ears and one mouth for a reason. You are supposed to listen twice as much.â€ Officer Ryan Burke, of the Moncks Corner Police Department, stressed the importance of keeping up with not only your mental health but your fellow officersâ€™ mental health. The suicide numbers seen in law enforcement officers can only be described by one word, OUTRAGEOUS. As a leader you are directly impacting those whom you lead. Take that opportunity to provide them with a positive atmosphere and build trust with them. Having that trust built between you and those you lead will open a line of communication. That line of communication could potentially save a life. A requirement for this class was to create a presentation on a leadership book. I crafted my presentation around the book titled, â€œLeading Beyond Traditionâ€, which was written by Chief William Cooper. This book was about how to modernize leadership in law enforcement. This book also provided the idea of continuous improvement. I closed my presentation by asking the following question, â€œThroughout the years of law enforcement, a classic phrase that is often said during trainings is get off the â€œXâ€. Why do law enforcement leaders have such a hard time implementing that into their leadership?â€ The amount of knowledge I have gained about leadership the past three days was undeniably the best experience I have had in this career.
